description: From Middle English footer, equivalent to foot +‎ -er.

entries.meaning: (computing) A line of information printed at the bottom of a page to identify the contents. (Compare foot in printing.)
(in combination) Something that measures a stated number of feet in some dimension.
examples: The new boat is a six-footer.

entries.meaning: (in combination) Someone who has a preference for using a certain foot.

description: 18th century.  From fouter, foutre (“valueless thing”), possibly from French foutre (“to lecher”), from Latin futuere, present active infinitive of futuō (“I fuck”).  Ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *bʰew- (“to hit”).

verbs.description: footer (third-person singular simple present footers, present participle footering, simple past and past participle footered)

entries.meaning: (Ireland and Scotland, slang) To meddle with or pass time without accomplishing anything meaningful.
examples: Synonyms: fidget, fuss, trifle; see also Thesaurus:loiter
